definitions: The maximum load an athlete can lift once with proper technique.
The heaviest weight that can be successfully completed for one full repetition.
A maximal strength benchmark representing a single successful rep at the highest load.
A test value used to prescribe training intensity as a percentage of maximum.
The greatest resistance that can be moved one time through the full ROM with correct form.
A reference maximum used for programming loads (e.g., 85% 1RM).
A single-rep ceiling for an exercise under standardized technique criteria.
The top load that can be lifted once without technical breakdown or assistance.
If an athlete exceeds the rep goal by 2+ reps on the last set for two consecutive sessions, increase the load.
A progression guideline using repeated over-performance to justify adding weight.
A rule to increase training load when target reps are surpassed consistently across two workouts.
A practical overload trigger: beat the rep target by at least two reps, twice in a row, on the final set.
A method for load progression based on performance above the planned repetition goal.
A decision rule to raise intensity when the athlete repeatedly demonstrates reserve capacity.
A progression criterion tying weight increases to repeated rep surplus on the last set.
A simple autoregulation-style rule that advances load after two straight rep-goal “wins.”
The muscle primarily responsible for producing a specific movement.
The main muscle generating force for an action at a joint.
The primary contributor to movement in a given exercise phase.
The muscle that shortens or generates the intended torque for the motion.
The dominant force-producing muscle in a movement pattern.
The principal muscle targeted when performing a specific joint action.
The main muscle acting to create the desired motion.
The prime mover that produces the majority of force for the action.
The muscle that opposes the action of the agonist.
A muscle that produces torque opposite the prime mover at a joint.
The opposing muscle group that can slow, control, or reverse movement.
A muscle that lengthens while the agonist shortens during a movement.
The muscle that counteracts the agonist’s action to stabilize or control motion.
A muscle that can act as a brake during deceleration or eccentric control.
The opposing muscle contributing to joint stability via co-contraction.
The muscle group performing the opposite joint action to the prime mover.
An exercise used to support a primary lift by strengthening key muscles or positions.
Accessory work chosen to improve performance in core/competition movements.
A secondary movement used to address weak links, technique limits, or hypertrophy needs.
An exercise that targets specific muscles to carry over to main lifts.
Supplemental training used after core lifts to build supportive strength.
A non-primary exercise selected to improve a primary exercise’s outcome.
A movement that helps correct imbalances or reinforce parts of a main lift.
Supporting exercises used to build capacity around the key performance lifts.
A series of exercises performed in sequence with minimal rest between stations.
Training organized as stations where multiple movements are completed back-to-back.
A method that alternates exercises rapidly to maintain an elevated heart rate.
Sequential exercise bouts with short rest that can emphasize muscular endurance and conditioning.
A workout structure where athletes rotate through multiple exercises in a set order.
A method that combines resistance exercises (and sometimes cardio) with limited rest.
A training format using short transitions to sustain workload density.
A sequence-based approach that increases total work per unit time.
Two exercises for the same muscle group performed consecutively with little rest.
Back-to-back movements targeting the same primary muscles.
A pairing method that increases local fatigue by repeating stress on one muscle group.
A set structure where two similar-target exercises are done without meaningful rest.
A technique to add volume and metabolic stress to a targeted muscle group.
Consecutive exercises emphasizing the same region (e.g., chest press then fly).
A paired set approach used to intensify focus on one muscle group.
Two sequential exercises for the same muscles with minimal transition time.
An exercise that recruits large muscle areas and involves two or more primary joints.
A foundational multijoint lift used as the main driver of training stimulus.
A primary movement that provides the greatest transfer to sport or key performance goals.
A large-muscle, multi-joint exercise typically performed early in the session.
A main lift emphasizing high force output and significant systemic demand.
A primary exercise around which assistance work is organized.
A multijoint movement that forms the backbone of a training session.
A key lift chosen for maximal training effect and broad muscular involvement.
An athlete’s prior experience with resistance training and specific exercises.
The record of what movements an athlete has practiced and adapted to over time.
Past exposure to training methods that influences current tolerance and response.
An overview of an athlete’s previous lifting experience and exercise familiarity.
A programming consideration describing the athlete’s accumulated exercise experience.
Prior experience that affects technique, load selection, and progression speed.
Background information on what the athlete has done before in training.
The athlete’s historical exposure to resistance exercise and movement patterns.
The sequence in which exercises are performed within a workout.
The planned arrangement of lifts from first to last in a session.
A programming variable that influences fatigue and performance on later exercises.
Typically: power → core multijoint → assistance → isolation (common sequencing logic).
The workout structure defining which movements occur earlier vs later.
A factor affecting intensity quality, technique, and total training output.
The prioritized sequence of exercises based on goals and fatigue management.
How exercises are arranged to maximize performance on the most important lifts.
Choosing exercises that match goals, sport demands, and athlete needs.
The process of picking lifts based on desired adaptations and movement patterns.
Selecting movements to address strengths, weaknesses, injury history, and equipment constraints.
Choosing the specific exercises that will comprise a training program.
A decision process aligning exercises with specificity, safety, and progression potential.
The selection of movements that best produce the targeted training stimulus.
Picking exercises that fit the athlete’s skill, mobility, and tolerance.
Choosing the best exercises to achieve performance outcomes efficiently.
An athlete’s proficiency in performing exercises with correct form.
The skill level an athlete has with a lift’s mechanics and execution.
Technical competency that affects load selection, safety, and training effect.
How well an athlete can maintain technique across fatigue and heavier loads.
A factor that determines whether complex lifts are appropriate in a program.
The athlete’s ability to perform an exercise consistently and correctly.
Movement skill that influences efficiency, performance, and injury risk.
The level of technical mastery an athlete has for a given exercise.
The planned number of repetitions to be completed in a set.
The rep target prescribed for the athlete for a given set.
A programming variable used to set intensity and training effect (strength vs hypertrophy).
The intended rep count for the set before accounting for fatigue or autoregulation.
The repetition objective used to evaluate performance and progression decisions.
A planned rep number that guides load selection and pacing.
The prescribed reps that define the set’s goal output.
The target rep count used to structure training volume and intensity.
Evaluation of injury history and risk factors to guide program design decisions.
A review of prior injuries, current symptoms, and movement limitations for safe training.
Identifying injury patterns and contraindications when selecting exercises and loads.
A screening process to reduce risk and select appropriate progressions.
Assessment of tissues/joints that require modification in volume, intensity, or exercise choice.
Considering injury susceptibility when planning training stress and technique demands.
Analyzing injury background to tailor exercise selection and loading strategies.
A program-design step focusing on safety and individualized constraints.
Load expressed relative to maximum capacity (often %1RM).
How heavy the resistance is compared with an athlete’s maximal ability.
A key training variable commonly quantified as percent of 1RM.
The magnitude of resistance that drives neural and strength adaptations.
Relative loading that influences repetitions possible and training effect.
How challenging the load is compared to the athlete’s max on that exercise.
The relative heaviness of the set rather than how hard it “feels.”
A prescription variable indicating load severity (e.g., 70% vs 90% 1RM).
The recovery period between sets of the same exercise.
Time allowed after a set before the next set begins.
A variable influencing energy system recovery and performance quality.
A programming factor that affects strength (longer rest) vs metabolic stress (shorter rest).
The between-set pause used to restore ATP-PCr and reduce fatigue.
Rest duration separating repeated sets to manage fatigue and maintain technique.
Planned recovery time between sets in a workout.
Set-to-set recovery interval.
The amount of external resistance used in an exercise.
The weight or resistance applied to the athlete during a movement.
A primary driver of mechanical tension and strength adaptation.
The external force demand imposed by the implement (barbell, dumbbell, machine).
The prescribed resistance for a given set or rep range.
The amount of weight selected based on intensity and goals.
Resistance magnitude applied to the body during training.
The external training stress in kilograms/pounds or equivalent resistance units.
Force applied multiplied by displacement in the direction of the force.
The product of force and distance moved (W = F × d).
Energy transferred when a force causes an object to move.
A physics-based quantity describing how much force moved an object through a distance.
Work done increases when either force or displacement increases.
A measure of energy expenditure related to moving a load through a range of motion.
In lifting: the work associated with moving the bar through its path under load.
A mechanical quantity distinct from power (rate of doing work).
Evaluation of sport-specific movement patterns and biomechanics.
Analyzing how athletes move in sport to identify key joints, velocities, and patterns.
A needs-analysis step that identifies critical movement actions and technical demands.
Reviewing game movements (e.g., sprinting, cutting, jumping) to guide exercise choice.
Assessing directional demands, ROM, and typical force/velocity characteristics of sport.
Analyzing the mechanics of sport tasks to match training specificity.
Studying movement patterns to identify performance limiters and injury risks.
Biomechanical evaluation of sport actions to inform program design.
An exercise involving movement at two or more joints.
A lift that recruits multiple muscle groups across multiple joints.
Compound movements such as squats, deadlifts, presses, rows, cleans.
Exercises that generally produce higher systemic stress and training effect per set.
Movements requiring coordination and stabilization across segments.
Lifts where more than one primary joint action occurs simultaneously.
A category of exercises typically prioritized for strength and power development.
A multi-articular movement pattern used to train integrated force production.
Appropriate strength relationships between opposing muscle groups.
A state where agonists and antagonists have balanced strength and control.
Proportional development across opposing movements (e.g., hamstrings/quads, push/pull).
Strength symmetry that supports joint stability and efficient movement.
Balanced muscular development that reduces injury risk from imbalances.
Appropriate ratios between muscle groups that act on the same joint.
Adequate opposing muscle capacity to decelerate and stabilize actions.
A program goal to prevent dominance of one muscle group over its counterpart.
Evaluating sport demands, athlete characteristics, and injury risks to guide program design.
A structured process to determine what qualities training should prioritize.
Analysis of sport tasks and athlete profile to select training methods and targets.
A planning step that integrates movement, physiological, and injury considerations.
The foundation of program design: what the sport requires and what the athlete needs.
A systematic review used to prioritize training goals and exercise selection.
Assessment of sport-specific requirements plus individual constraints and strengths/weaknesses.
A decision framework to align training with performance demands.
Applying greater stress than previously encountered to stimulate adaptation.
A principle stating the body adapts only when challenged beyond its current level.
Increasing training demand to force physiological and performance changes.
A requirement for improvement: stress must exceed habitual levels.
Overload can be achieved by raising load, volume, density, complexity, or velocity demands.
A foundational training concept necessary for strength, hypertrophy, and conditioning gains.
Progressively increasing stimulus so the body must adapt.
The systematic application of a higher training stress to drive adaptation.
Assessment of the metabolic and energy system demands of a sport.
Evaluating whether sport demands are primarily anaerobic power, capacity, aerobic endurance, etc.
A needs-analysis component focusing on intensity, duration, and recovery patterns.
Analyzing predominant energy pathways and fatigue patterns in sport performance.
Determining key conditioning qualities (e.g., repeated sprint ability, VO2 demands).
Studying work-to-rest ratios and intensity distribution to guide conditioning design.
A review of sport physiology requirements to inform training emphasis.
Assessment of energy system contribution and conditioning priorities.
An exercise emphasizing high force production at high movement velocity.
A movement performed explosively to maximize rate of force development and speed.
Exercises like Olympic lift derivatives, jumps, throws, and explosive presses.
A training category designed to increase power output (force × velocity).
Movements requiring rapid acceleration of a load or body mass.
Exercises performed with intent to move fast rather than grind heavy reps.
Training that prioritizes speed-strength and explosiveness.
Explosive movements aimed at maximizing mechanical power.
A summary of an athlete’s performance characteristics and capacities.
A compiled overview of strengths, weaknesses, and key metrics from testing and observation.
A snapshot of an athlete’s current abilities across multiple domains.
A set of data describing the athlete’s physical qualities and readiness.
A summary used to guide goal setting and program priorities.
An athlete’s measured and observed capabilities used for planning training.
A performance summary that helps target limiting factors.
A descriptive record of the athlete’s current status and attributes.
Systematic planning of training variables to meet performance goals.
Organizing exercises, volume, intensity, frequency, and progression into a coherent plan.
The process of building a periodized training plan aligned with sport demands and athlete needs.
Planning training structure to produce specific adaptations while managing fatigue and risk.
Selecting and sequencing training phases and sessions to achieve targeted outcomes.
Designing workouts and cycles based on needs analysis and progression principles.
A decision process integrating exercise selection, order, rest, and progression strategies.
The structured creation of a training plan that drives adaptation safely and effectively.
A systematic increase in training stress over time.
Planned advancement of training variables to continue adaptation.
Gradually increasing load, volume, density, or complexity as capacity improves.
A methodical approach to making training more challenging across sessions or blocks.
A programming strategy that prevents stagnation by raising stimulus appropriately.
The stepwise escalation of training demands to drive improvement.
Advancing the training plan as the athlete adapts.
An organized increase in difficulty across time.
Low-intensity activity used to facilitate recovery between training sessions.
Light movement aimed at promoting blood flow and reducing stiffness.
Exercise performed below taxing intensity to support restoration rather than adaptation stress.
Active recovery designed to aid readiness without adding meaningful fatigue.
Low-demand movement such as easy cycling, walking, mobility, or light tempo work.
A recovery-focused session used to improve restoration and reduce residual soreness.
Light exercise intended to accelerate recovery processes.
Submaximal activity used to maintain movement and promote recovery.
One complete movement of an exercise.
A single cycle of the lifting motion from start to finish.
One full execution of the movement pattern through the prescribed ROM.
A single completed performance of the exercise.
One full concentric-eccentric (or defined) movement cycle of a lift.
The basic counting unit within a set.
A single complete lift performed with correct technique.
One completed movement repetition.
The maximum load that can be lifted for a given number of repetitions.
The heaviest weight that can be completed for a specified rep count (e.g., 5RM).
A strength measure defined by failure at the target rep under proper form.
A load prescription reference point used for intensity planning without testing 1RM.
The maximal load sustainable for exactly N repetitions.
A capacity metric: maximum weight for a set rep target.
A repetition-specific maximal strength benchmark.
The greatest load possible for a given reps-to-fatigue value.
The total number of repetitions performed in a workout or session.
Sum of all reps completed across sets (and potentially exercises) in a session.
A volume metric describing repetition count independent of load.
Total reps accumulated for an exercise or muscle group in a workout.
A training quantity that influences fatigue and hypertrophy when accumulated sufficiently.
The aggregate rep count used to quantify workload density and volume.
A measure of how many reps were completed overall.
Total repetition count across the workout.
Time allowed for recovery between sets or exercises.
The planned pause separating work bouts in resistance training.
A programming variable influencing performance, fatigue, and energy system recovery.
Longer rest supports strength and power quality; shorter rest increases metabolic stress.
Recovery time between efforts used to manage training density and intensity.
The interval between sets/exercises that affects total training output.
A planned recovery window used to restore readiness for the next effort.
The time between work bouts in a training session.
Specific Adaptations to Imposed Demands: adaptations match the type of training stress applied.
A principle stating the body adapts specifically to the demands placed upon it.
Training effects are specific to the mode, intensity, volume, and movement pattern used.
A reminder that you get better at what you repeatedly practice and stress.
Adaptations reflect the exact stimulus: muscles, joints, velocities, and energy systems involved.
A rule explaining why specificity drives transfer to sport performance.
The body’s response is tailored to the imposed training demands.
Adaptations are not general; they are stimulus-specific.
A group of repetitions performed consecutively.
A block of reps completed without extended rest.
A discrete work bout within an exercise prescription.
A prescribed cluster of repetitions separated from others by rest.
A unit of training volume (e.g., 3 sets of 5 reps).
A series of consecutive reps performed as one effort.
A repeated work segment for an exercise.
A defined group of reps before resting.
An exercise involving movement at only one joint.
A movement designed to target a specific muscle group with minimal joint involvement.
Isolation work such as leg extension (knee), biceps curl (elbow), calf raise (ankle).
Exercises with one primary joint action dominating the movement.
Movements that often allow focused hypertrophy or rehab with lower coordination demands.
A category of exercises that reduces systemic fatigue compared to multi-joint lifts.
Exercises where one joint primarily moves through ROM.
Single-articular training movements.
Training adaptations are specific to the type of exercise performed.
A principle stating improvements are greatest in the movements and demands that are trained.
Adaptation depends on similarity between training stimulus and performance task.
The closer training matches sport demands, the greater the transfer.
A rule guiding exercise selection, velocity, ROM, and energy system emphasis.
Specificity explains why skill, movement pattern, and intensity matter for performance gains.
Adaptations occur in the specific muscles, patterns, and energy systems stressed.
A programming principle aligning training with desired outcomes.
A schedule dividing muscle groups or movement patterns across different training days.
A weekly plan that distributes training volume across sessions (e.g., upper/lower).
A structure that allows higher volume per muscle group by separating sessions.
A routine organizing workouts by body regions, lifts, or movement patterns.
A programming approach that manages fatigue by spreading work across the week.
A training schedule format (push/pull/legs, upper/lower, etc.).
A method of dividing training focus into separate days.
A weekly organization strategy for resistance training sessions.
A multijoint exercise that loads the spine and requires postural stabilization.
A lift that challenges trunk stiffness and whole-body support under axial load.
Exercises like squats, deadlifts, overhead presses, cleans (context dependent).
Movements requiring significant torso and hip stabilization while producing force.
A category typically performed early due to high systemic demand and technique requirement.
Large, spine-loading compound lifts that demand strong posture control.
Exercises placing meaningful compressive/shear demands on the axial skeleton.
Multijoint lifts that require stabilizing the spine under load.
Two exercises performed consecutively with minimal rest.
A paired set format commonly using opposing muscle groups (e.g., push then pull).
A method to increase training density by reducing rest between different movements.
Back-to-back exercises with little transition time to save time and increase workload.
A pairing technique that can maintain performance by alternating muscle groups.
Two exercises done in sequence before taking a longer rest.
A session structure for efficiency and increased work per unit time.
Consecutive exercises with minimal rest, often arranged as antagonist pairs.
An athlete’s cumulative experience with physical training.
The total training exposure that shapes adaptation, tolerance, and skill.
A history of what the athlete has done across strength, conditioning, and sport work.
A factor that influences progression rate, injury risk, and program complexity.
Overall training experience level used to classify novice, intermediate, advanced status.
The athlete’s accumulated practice and conditioning history.
Past training volume, intensity, and modalities that affect current readiness.
A summary of long-term training experience and adaptation.
The number of training sessions performed per week.
How often an athlete trains in a given time period.
A program variable describing session count per week for a lift, muscle group, or total plan.
How many exposures to training stimuli occur each week.
A driver of skill practice opportunities and volume distribution.
Weekly session rate that influences recovery needs and workload planning.
The schedule-based repetition of training sessions over the week.
Number of training exposures per week.
An athlete’s current level of fitness and adaptation.
The present conditioning and strength level resulting from recent training.
A snapshot of preparedness influenced by training history and current phase.
Current adaptation level that affects how much stimulus is needed for progress.
A classification of current fitness and readiness (not just experience).
The athlete’s current capability and tolerance for training stress.
Current performance capacity based on recent training consistency and recovery.
An athlete’s present level of conditioning and training adaptation.
The total amount of work performed, often expressed as sets × reps.
A workload quantity describing how much training is completed.
Total training amount accumulated for a muscle group or exercise.
A programming variable commonly measured as total sets and reps (and sometimes load).
The quantity of training that contributes strongly to hypertrophy and fatigue.
How much work is performed over a session, week, or block.
A measure of training amount independent of intensity details (sometimes).
Total work quantity commonly approximated via sets and repetitions.
Total training load calculated as sets × repetitions × load.
A workload metric combining volume and intensity into one value.
The sum of weight lifted across all reps and sets (often called tonnage).
A quantification of total external load moved during a workout or period.
A planning metric used to compare workload across sessions or blocks.
Total lifted load computed by multiplying reps and sets by the weight used.
A way to express total work with resistance across a training bout.
Sets × reps × weight used across the session (or exercise).
